is located just south of the
, Saratoga Springs is a pleasant town filled with swanky shops, spas and horse racing. A key battle in the Revolution War happened nearby. Saratoga Springs is home to Skidmore College.
. Enjoy this tree lined drive along I-87, also called the Adirondack Northway.
has a station on the aptly named Station Lane about a mile from downtown. Service between

value: http://www.sncrr.com Saratoga and North Creek Railroad

is a new (July 2011) railroad with service from the Saratoga Springs Amtrak station to the Adironack village of North Creek, with flag stops at seven other intermediate stations.  Service is offered three times a day Thursday through Monday in historic dome cars.  The morning train is timed to coordinate with Amtrak service.  A great way to see the Adirondacks without driving.

value: , in conjunction with other bus carriers, offers service to Saratoga from both the north and south. Buses that originate in
stop here several times a day.
. The bus stop is located at the Saratoga Raceway Casino, near the Nelson Avenue entrance and CDTA bus stop. Fares from $1 and up.
operates local buses in the Albany area. Several routes operate to and within Saratoga Springs, including a Saratoga Visitors Trolley.

, but you will need to use public transport or a car to reach the world famous Saratoga Race Track
. There is so much to see and do in the downtown area of Saratoga Springs. Enjoy culture and history in the diverse city of

value: Saratoga Springs Urban Cultural Park Visitor Center
, I-87 to exit 13N. Take Route 9 north for 3 miles to park, Phone: +1 518 584-2535,
. Year round. Dubbed "The Public's Resort", this park has mineral baths, eighteen hole and nine hole golf courses

, free hardtop and clay tennis courts, and several pool areas with showers, locker rooms, rest rooms and food concessions. Hiking (and cross country/snowshoe) trails and picnic areas complete with grills are available as well. The park encompasses and protects the mineral springs in use at least as far back as the 14th century. This "Queen of Spas" was a 19th century vacation retreat for the rich and famous.
content=Canfield Casino Bldg, Congress Park. Summer 10AM-4PM. Other seasons W-Sa 10AM-4PM, Su 1PM-4PM. Housed in an 1870 casino. Adults $5, ages 12-17 $3.
content=Summer: 9:30AM-4:30PM. Winter hours (Labor Day through June): Tu-Sa 9:30AM-4:30PM, Su noon-4:30PM. $5, under age 1 free.
content=Route 9P. Artist community on four hundred acre site.
name=National Museum of Racing & Hall of Fame
hours=M-Sa 10AM-4PM, Su 12PM-4PM (Closed M,Tu in Jan. and Feb.)
content= A place to experience the history of one of Saratoga's most popular attractions, thoroughbred racing. Something for everyone with interactive exhibits, rare memorabilia, and equine art.
name=Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery
content= Summer home of the New York City Ballet, the Philadelphia Orchestra and various concerts such as The Dave Matthews Band.

Located 4 miles southeast of Saratoga Springs. This 8 1/2 mile long lake has a public boat launch at the north end, as well as several private marinas. Popular activities include bass fishing, sailing, boating, water skiing, and ice fishing.

content=Located 4 exits north of Saratoga, exit 19 on I-87. This once and a lifetime experience is not to be missed. Enjoy the gorgeous views of the Adirondack Region and the Green Mountains of Vermont from high in the sky with some of the most experienced ballooning crews.

time to come to Saratoga is during the Thoroughbred season, which is five or so weeks in July, August and September. The premier race here is the Travers, but every day in the season thousands flock from around

and points behind to the see the ponies. That said, if you find yourself in town during other times of the year, check out some of the smaller tracks. Indoor gambling places are available for those who have a gambling urge during the winter months.

value: content=Horse racing from late July to early September.
content= Harness racing and video gaming.
content=Towering pines surround this 7,100 yard course.
content=Eighteen holes with lots of up/down.
content= Named 2005 "Golf Course of the Year" by National Golf Course Owners Association. Named "One of America's 100 Greatest Public Courses 2005-2006" by Golf Digest.
content=For more information on the sport of golf, its history, and courses near to you. Enjoy golfing in Saratoga County.
. Offering bachelors and/or graduate degrees in over 30 areas of study, as well as the "University Without Walls" degree completion program.

, but it does have plenty of boutiques and shops that cater to that particular crowd. No matter what your style is, Saratoga Springs is full of chic boutiques, trendy antique stores and a wide variety of eclectic shops to satisfy any style. Start on Broadway and find local crafts, haute fashion and other merchandise for that platinum card.

value: 436 Broadway, +1 518 584-4665. Open Daily. V/MC/AE accepted. This specialty boutique located downtown is known for elegant fine fashions and accessories. Designers include Eileen Fisher, Singrid Olsenand, and Michael Stars.

content= This Gallery/Workshop is where designer and goldsmith Dennis deJonghe creates his one of a kind jewelry out of fine gems and precious metals. It features his equestrian collection, as well as sample wedding bands and other original designs.

456 Broadway +1 518 583-9452. Open Daily. This Irish gift shop has only the best from Ireland, Scotland, and Wales. Pottery, china, jewelry, music, books, posters and prints, sweaters and caps are all available at this charming establishment.
content= Open Daily, shipping available. A large selection of Saratoga related paintings and prints, as well as thoroughbred photos. This local favorite is a great place for gifts.

High Rock Park. +1 518 893-2669 Open Wed 3-6PM, Sat 9AM-1PM. This open air market is home to a variety of homemade goods, crafts, and foods. The market is a must and has been serving the locals for over 25 years.
content=V/M accepted. This "shop with a heart" has 24 lines of dolls to choose from. Play dolls as well as porcelain and vinyl collectibles are available in a variety of price ranges.
content= Find the hottest fashions for women and teens. Find trend driven clothing perfect for your style. Designs by Ed Hardy, Sky, Sweetees, Blue Cult, David Kahn, Unyx, Steve Madden and more.

Saratoga has some of the best dining in upstate New York. Chéfs from

have emigrated northward to ensure that there's food for every palette. Most of the finest restaurants can be found on or near Broadway. Keep in mind that some places aren't open outside of the tourist season.

There's also plenty of choice for those less discriminating taste buds or smaller budgets. Pub grub, American specials and small diners abound. And if you're hungry at 2AM, be sure to ask a local where you can get a doughboy. They're great.

value: content= Warm rustic steak and seafood place right on the strip. Private parties and banquets upstairs in Diamond Jim's.
content=Early morning breakfast.fast! Opens when the bars close.
content= Specialty food store and deli.
content=Jazz with dinner, reservations or wait required but worth it.
content=Great courtyard dining during track season, indoor and pub dining available.
hours=Su Mo 11AM-12AM, Tu W 11AM-2AM, Th 11AM-3AM, Fr Sa 11AM-4AM

content=Pizza and a doughboy and you're ready for anything. Take them out for a stroll. Originally at 6 1/2 Caroline, the restaurant moved its location in August 2009 to provide an expanded dining area.
content=Trendy Italian restaurant, amazing lounge, seafood pasta and vino. Per morire per!
content=Viva De Mexico, best mex going! Away from downtown but near the track.
content=Located in a renovated Victorian house, this sister restaurant to One Caroline Street Bistro specializes in locally-sourced cuisine with a Cajun flair. Try the Crawfish Beignets!
content= Upscale French bistro located at The Saratoga.
content="Hattie" may have long since passed, but her Cajun tastes are still reflected on the menu, which includes her signature fired chicken.
content=South Broadway (US Route 9). Barbecue chicken and ribs; includes two 20-foot barbecue pits out in the back. Located about one mile from the Northway, open year-round.
content=A unique menu featuring savory and sweet crepes for lunch, dinner, and weekend brunch.
name=Four Seasons Natural Food Store & Cafe

content=This vegetarian spot has a variety of soups, salads, and hot en trees. While you are there, check out the retail store which offers a selection of natural foods,teas,supplements, and personal care and organic produce.
content=Check out the famous wood fired pizza and homemade soups.
content=Good location for weddings, businesses meetings or private gatherings.
hours=Mo-Th 11AM-11PM, Fr Sa 11AM-11:30PM, Su and Holidays 12PM-11PM
content=If you're in the mood for Chinese, look no further than this delicious spot downtown. Good price, great food, and also serves Thai.
name=The Merry Monk Restaurant and Bar
content=Classic bistro decor makes this a great spot for cocktails or dinner. Ask for a corner banquette table to enjoy a cozy meal for two and listen to the funky world beat soundtrack.
content=Serves coffee, bagels, bagel sandwiches and such. A local favorite.

content=Pizzaworks is a family pizzeria. Their hand tossed New York style, thin crust pizza is based of a traditional Italian family recipe. They also serve a variety of subs, wings, calzones, stromboli, wraps, salads and appetizers including bread sticks and garlic knots.

Saratoga has no lack of choices if what you desire is a hop-or-two. Fine Irish Pubs to trendy ultra-light-serving watering holes abound. If wine is what makes you feel fine, you will.

will be more than happy to help you. Even if they have to run across town to get exactly what you want, literally!

The wineries from New York's Fingerlakes region have been maturing very well and can be found on most lists. The pages of more established varieties from California, Australia, France and Italy sometimes make your head spin before you sip. If you get the chance attend one of the many wine tastings. They are available both for the novice and the Guru of the Grape.

value: content=This place introduced a young Bob Dylan to the world. Claims to be America's oldest continuously operating folk coffeehouse.
content=Singer Don McLean is said to have composed his
while sitting at a table in this bar. A plaque marks the table today. A 1930s era saloon.
content=This local favorite had tons to offer, live music and great food add to the appeal of this one of a kind bar.
content=A great place to watch football on Sundays, or start out your night. Inexpensive and the best specials in town.
content=Classic bistro decor makes this a great spot for cocktails or dinner. Ask for a corner banquette table to enjoy a cozy meal for two and listen to the funky world beat soundtrack.
content=A Caroline Street institution since who-knows-when.

content=Located in the Art District, this bar and restaurant offers comfortable atmosphere,Italian American cuisine and quality service at a reasonable cost. Great spot for a first date to dinner with the family.

Saratoga Springs has a number of different accommodation options ranging from budget chain motels to quaint (and often historic) bed and breakfasts.

value: content=Free Wi-Fi, indoor pool, pet-friendly, free hot breakfast.

Saratoga Springs is in the 518 area code. The ZIP code is 12866.

Saratoga Springs is relatively safe for a city its size. However, the bars along Caroline Street can get a bit rowdy late in the week and on weekends.
